g.text: Diagonal nematicity in the pseudogap phase
The pseudogap phenomenon in the cuprates is arguably the most mysterious puzzle in the
ﬁeld of high-temperature superconductivity. The tetragonal cuprate HgBa
layer per primitive cell, is an ideal system to tackle this puzzle. Here, we measure
the magnetic susceptibility anisotropy within the CuO
precision magnetic torque experiments. Our key ﬁnding is that a distinct two-fold in-plane
anisotropy sets in below the pseudogap temperature
evidence for a nematic phase transition with broken four-fold symmetry. Surprisingly, the
nematic director orients along the diagonal direction of the CuO
contrast to the bond nematicity along the Cu-O-Cu direction. Another remarkable feature is
that the enhancement of the diagonal nematicity with decreasing temperature is suppressed
around the temperature at which short-range charge-density-wave formation occurs. Our
result suggests a competing relationship between diagonal nematic and charge-density-wave
Department of Physics, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606-8502, Japan.
Department of Advanced Materials Science, University of Tokyo, Chiba 277-8561,
Materials Dynamics Laboratory, RIKEN SPring-8 Center, 1-1-1 Kouto, Sayo, Hyogo 679-5148, Japan.

43210-1117, USA. Correspondence and requests for materials should be addressed to Y.M. (email:
